clinical_study.brief_title: Feasibility Trial of a Mobile Adherence Tool for Adolescents With Asthma
clinical_study.official_title: Feasibility of a Mobile Intervention to Increase Adherence to Asthma Medication Among Children Age 11 to 19 in an Urban Setting

collaborator.agency: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess the feasibility of using a mobile health intervention to improve adherence to asthma medication among adolescents in an urban clinic setting. The intervention consists of an inhaler sensor strap to monitor asthma inhaler use and a mobile phone application to remind and incentivize patients to use their medication. This study will assess the feasibility and acceptability of this intervention to patients.

primary_outcome.measure: Evidence of ability to monitor medication use at home via a sensor strap
primary_outcome.description: Ability to measure medication use via the sensor strap and upload that information to the HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act) compliant server.

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient feedback for improved design of a mobile adherence tool
secondary_outcome.description: Feedback from patients on the design of the inhaler sensor and mobile app including aesthetics and ease of use.

secondary_outcome.measure: Acceptability of mobile adherence strategy for adolescents with asthma (Based on questions as part of baseline/followup visits and focus group.)
secondary_outcome.description: Based on questions as part of baseline/followup visits and focus group.

arm_group.description: Patients in this arm were given no intervention. Their self-reported medication adherence was assessed at the baseline (week 0) and follow-up (week 12) visits but during the study period they did not receive any intervention.

These patients received the medication use sensor (sham intervention) and downloaded a sham version of the mobile app. Thus, the medication use from these patients was able to be recorded but the patients did not receive reminders or incentives or the ability to see their medication use via the real mobile app. Intervention: inhaler sensor
These patients received the medication use sensor and the mobile app with reminders (intervention arm). Interventions: inhaler sensor and mobile application for asthma adherence

intervention.description: Inhaler sensor strap that tracks inhaler use via a pressure sensitive switch.
Mobile phone application that sends reminders, allows patients to see their medication use, and provides points and other incentives for medication use.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 11-19
- Asthma diagnosis
- Currently on a daily controller medication for Asthma
- English-speaking
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant
- Foster Care
- Emancipated minor
